title: Scared of speaking English?
intro: Do you ever feel scared to speak in English? Lots of people find speaking a different language stressful. Beth and Pippa talk about learning languages and how to fight your fears of speaking English.
this_week_question: English has around one million words, but on average, how many words does a typical English speaker use in daily conversation?
a) between 2000 and 3000 b) between 20000 and 30000 c) between 200000 and 300000
Listen to the programme to hear the answer.

vocab.desc: used as a modifier to mean quiet, a bit
understand, usually because you've experienced something similar
feeling nervous or worried about something that's happening or that might happen in the future
beliefs that are based on things that are not true, that are not logical

transcript.text: Yes, I learnt French when I was younger and I was actually quite good at it, I think, but I was really nervous when I was speaking French. How about you?

transcript.author: Beth

transcript.author: Pippa

transcript.text: My English was actually pretty good but having conversations with people, I found it really difficult. My results were pretty good and I was fluent. But on that very same day, leaving the building and going to get some coffee, I couldn't really understand what the barista was saying, and I felt pretty nervous to order coffee and was trying to stress every single word, hoping that my grammar is correct and I am pronouncing the words right.

transcript.text: Yeah, I'm sure that's a situation lots of people can relate to .

transcript.text: Hanan's results on her English assessment were pretty good, but she was still pretty nervous to speak in English, for example when ordering a coffee in English. The modifier pretty means quite or a bit.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Georgie says that Hanan's experience is something that lots of people can relate to . If you relate to a situation, you know what it feels like, usually because a similar thing has happened to you.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: So lots of people feel nervous speaking another language, even if they're good at it, like Hanan We can call this speaking anxiety . Anxiety means an uncomfortable feeling or worry about something that is happening or could happen in the future.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: So why do so many people have anxiety about speaking a foreign language? Experts think it's connected to the beliefs we have about ourselves. Han Luo, professor of Chinese at Lafayette College in the United States, explains more to BBC Learning English presenter Georgie.

transcript.text: Han says some people who have speaking anxiety have low self-perceptions . Your self-perception is what you think about yourself.

transcript.author: Beth

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Irrational beliefs are beliefs about something that is not true. They're not logical.

transcript.author: Beth
